awd_titl_txt: Rationality of Harm Avoidance and Political Tolerance
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines how to increase tolerance and openness to disagreement. It is based on a consideration of the fundamental human motivation to avoid harm. Not only do people avoid harm to themselves, people also think it reasonable for others to avoid harm. It is therefore expected that people will be more tolerant of opposing viewpoints when those viewpoints are seen as being motivated by the avoidance of harm.  Framing social viewpoints in terms of harm avoidance may make those with opposing views seem more rational.  Six studies explore how to increase tolerance using the idea of rationality of harm avoidance.  The long-term goal of the research is to provide a strong foundation to inform efforts aimed at reducing intolerance, and enhancing positive interactions with those with opposing viewpoints.

This project tests whether the fundamental human motivation to avoid harm can be leveraged to increase tolerance. Six studies examine people's willingness to interact with those with different views and their willingness to allow the expression of opposing views. The approach is to harness multiple methods, including laboratory experiments, archival studies, and nationally representative surveys. The experiments will be pre-registered and adhere to best practices of open science. Mediational analyses will test for the predicted pathway from harm avoidance to tolerance via perceived vulnerability and rationality.  The survey and behavioral studies will test other effects of the tolerance produced by the rationality of harm avoidance intervention. By emphasizing the universal human motivation to avoid harm, this project will transform scientific understanding of tolerance, and extend the research literatures on mind perception and intergroup empathy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Political polarization is at an all-time high in America and abroad (e.g. the UK), and this polarization is undermining many social enterprises. People of all political stripes report losing friends to political disagreement. This research provides on empirically backed way of increasing respect and the willingness to engage with political opponents, enabling people with diverse ideological viewpoints to work together in industry, commerce, and the government.  Beyond its large-scale applications, the research also seeks to make every day interactions more pleasant between those who disagree about political issues, whether in your work team or at your Thanksgiving dinner.

We conducted 17 rigorous studies evaluating the key hypothesis, that personal experiences — namely those involving suffering harm — would increase respect towards political opponents. We first documented that people's intuitions about fostering political respect lead them astray. Americans generally believe that emphasizing facts are the key to fostering respect (see figure: Intuitions about Respect). We believe that if we can just get down to the key statistics (without editorializing or stories) then we can find common ground. It turns out, that's not the case, because people disagree about the basic facts when it comes to political disagreement.

We then empirically tested the ability for personal experiences versus facts to increase respect. Across many different kinds of samples, including representative samples of Americans, and many different paradigms, such as archival analyses of interview transcripts from Fox News and CNN, evaluations of New York Times, and in person conversations in North Carolina, we found that personal experiences consistently increase respect between political opponents more than facts.

Across all the studies, we found support for our core model (Figure: Validated model), in which emphasizing personal experiences (vs. facts) and conversations effectively increases respect by making political opponents seem more rational. Specifically, it is personal experiences about avoiding harm that engender perceptions of rationality (Figure: Sharing Harmful Experiences). Even if we disagree with another person's view on a political issue, we can all appreciate the rationality of someone wanting to escape suffering, whether for them of their family. It's one thing to hear someone spout off statistics, it's another thing to hear about how someone suffered with respect to a particular issue, such as losing a job or getting ill. In other words, while philosophers and scientists have long understood rationality as tied to facts and statistics, in everyday conversation about politics, people seem to perceive someone is more rational when they base their views on experiences rather than facts.

Part of this increased perception of rationality is driven by the perceived truth of personal experiences. No matter your political affiliation, people tend to see personal experiences as more true than a set of relevant statistics.

This program of research has both intellectual merit and broader impact. In terms of intellectual merit, the revealed ability of personal experiences to foster respect stands in contrast to both everyday intuitions and to how science understands the persuasive ability of facts. The ability of this research to shape scientific understanding is reflected in the fact that this set of studies was published in the Proceeding of the National Academy of Sciences, in a paper that — in less than a year after publication — has been read 85,000 times.

In terms of broader impact, this work provides concrete and actionable way for people to have political discussions in such a way that it fosters respect. Note that this work does not require that anyone change their views (that is, it doesn't explore persuasion) but only investigates how people can maintain their moral convictions while still fostering respect across political divides, a goal that benefits all Americans touched by political discord. To further disseminate these results, we published a wide reaching op ed in USA Today and gave many talks on these results across the academy.

Altogether, this work provides a new understanding of how to build respect in political disagreement, something that both scientists and everyday people can appreciate.
